Meyer and Anne Viguier.</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="264" ind1=" " ind2="1"><subfield code="a">Paris :</subfield><subfield code="b">Open Edition,</subfield><subfield code="c">2020.</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="300" ind1=" " ind2=" "><subfield code="a">1 online resource.</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="336" ind1=" " ind2=" "><subfield code="a">text</subfield><subfield code="b">txt</subfield><subfield code="2">rdacontent</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="337" ind1=" " ind2=" "><subfield code="a">computer</subfield><subfield code="b">c</subfield><subfield code="2">rdamedia</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="338" ind1=" " ind2=" "><subfield code="a">online resource</subfield><subfield code="b">cr</subfield><subfield code="2">rdacarrier</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="490" ind1="0" ind2=" "><subfield code="a">Open Access e-Books</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="500" ind1=" " ind2=" "><subfield code="a">Volume 1 : sources et genres historiques (Tome 1 et Tome 2).</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="506" ind1="0" ind2=" "><subfield code="a">Free-to-read</subfield><subfield code="f">Unrestricted online access</subfield><subfield code="2">star</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="520" ind1=" " ind2=" "><subfield code="a">What relationships do human societies have with their past and what stories do they make of bygone times? For this first volume of the Encyclopedia of Historiographies. Africas, Americas, Asia, 157 specialists representing 88 academic institutions in France and around the world explore the world of human productions which constitute sources for the historian and decipher the many modalities ("scientific", literary, artistic, monumental ...) of writing from the past. Evoking in turn Africa, Latin America, Asia, Oceania, the 216 notices of the work present historical materials of all kinds, from all periods, often little known, as well as history of their uses. The collective enterprise that is the Encyclopedia aims to be innovative: it is a question of giving rise to a resolutely non-Western-centered historiographical reflection which usefully complements traditional epistemological approaches. A new historical knowledge tool forged in the age of globalization, the Encyclopedia of Historiographies is also a real invitation to travel.--</subfield><subfield code="c">Provided by publisher.</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="650" ind1=" " ind2="0"><subfield code="a">Historiography.</subfield><subfield Paris : Open Edition, 2020. 1 online resource. text txt rdacontent computer c rdamedia online resource cr rdacarrier Open Access e-Books Volume 1 : sources et genres historiques (Tome 1 et Tome 2). Free-to-read Unrestricted online access star What relationships do human societies have with their past and what stories do they make of bygone times? For this first volume of the Encyclopedia of Historiographies. Africas, Americas, Asia, 157 specialists representing 88 academic institutions in France and around the world explore the world of human productions which constitute sources for the historian and decipher the many modalities ("scientific", literary, artistic, monumental ...) of writing from the past. Evoking in turn Africa, Latin America, Asia, Oceania, the 216 notices of the work present historical materials of all kinds, from all periods, often little known, as well as history of their uses. The collective enterprise that is the Encyclopedia aims to be innovative: it is a question of giving rise to a resolutely non-Western-centered historiographical reflection which usefully complements traditional epistemological approaches. A new historical knowledge tool forged in the age of globalization, the Encyclopedia of Historiographies is also a real invitation to travel.-- Provided by publisher. notes_summary_ssim: What relationships do human societies have with their past and what stories do they make of bygone times? For this first volume of the Encyclopedia of Historiographies. Africas, Americas, Asia, 157 specialists representing 88 academic institutions in France and around the world explore the world of human productions which constitute sources for the historian and decipher the many modalities ("scientific", literary, artistic, monumental ...) of writing from the past. Evoking in turn Africa, Latin America, Asia, Oceania, the 216 notices of the work present historical materials of all kinds, from all periods, often little known, as well as history of their uses. The collective enterprise that is the Encyclopedia aims to be innovative: it is a question of giving rise to a resolutely non-Western-centered historiographical reflection which usefully complements traditional epistemological approaches. A new historical knowledge tool forged in the age of globalization, the Encyclopedia of Historiographies is also a real invitation to travel.--
